importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date when the Tel Aviv soccer derby was canceled due to violent riots, marking a significant incident in Israeli sports and public order.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period immediately before and during the match, when tensions rose, riots occurred, and decisions were made to cancel the game.

keyTakeAways: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled by Israeli police after violent riots and public disorder, with injuries reported among civilians and police.
Footage showed fans throwing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades, prompting authorities to cite endangerment of human life as the reason for cancellation.
Hapoel criticized the police response, alleging a militarized approach inconsistent with a sporting event.
The incident follows previous security concerns involving Maccabi fans, including a ban in England due to prior violent incidents abroad.
UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the English police ban, stating it was wrong and emphasized the importance of fan safety and inclusion.
Downing Street acknowledged the Tel Aviv incident and expressed intent to collaborate with Israeli authorities to understand the events.
Maccabi has not publicly commented beyond confirming the match cancellation.

namedEntities.name: Tel Aviv
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A city in Israel, the location of the soccer derby and the site of the violent riots.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The derby took place in Tel Aviv, and the violent public disorder occurred there, making the city central to the incident.

namedEntities.name: Hapoel
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli football club based in Tel Aviv, one of the rivals in the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Hapoel was directly involved in the match that was canceled, and criticized the police response.

namedEntities.name: Maccabi
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An Israeli football club based in Tel Aviv, the rival of Hapoel in the derby.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maccabi was involved in the match cancellation and has been previously linked to violent incidents abroad.

namedEntities.name: Israel Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency in Israel responsible for maintaining public order.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Israel Police canceled the match due to public disorder and injured civilians and officers, and their response was contested by Hapoel.

namedEntities.name: Bloomfield Stadium
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A shared stadium in Tel Aviv where the derby was scheduled to be played.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The match was supposed to take place at Bloomfield Stadium, where fans clashed with police both inside and outside.

namedEntities.name: Aston Villa
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: An English football club, the venue of a previous match involving Maccabi fans.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Maccabi fans were banned from attending a Europa League match at Aston Villa due to security concerns, linking past incidents to current unrest.

namedEntities.name: West Midlands Police
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The law enforcement agency in England that banned Maccabi fans from attending a game in England.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: They issued the ban based on intelligence and previous violent incidents, contributing to international attention on fan safety and policing.

namedEntities.name: Keir Starmer
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Prime Minister of the United Kingdom, who publicly condemned the ban on Maccabi fans.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Starmer criticized the UK police decision, emphasizing fan inclusion and safety, and acknowledged the Tel Aviv incident as part of broader concerns.

namedEntities.name: Ajax
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A Dutch football club, where Maccabi fans were involved in violent scenes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This past incident in Amsterdam highlights a history of violence involving Maccabi fans, contributing to security concerns abroad.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Tel Aviv soccer derby between Hapoel and Maccabi was canceled due to violent riots and public disorder, with police reporting injuries to 12 civilians and three officers, and nine arrests. Footage showed fans throwing pyrotechnics and smoke grenades, prompting the decision to cancel the match for safety reasons. Hapoel criticized the police response, claiming it resembled a war scenario rather than a sporting event. The incident follows previous security concerns involving Maccabi fans, including bans in England due to past violent incidents at matches in Aston Villa and against Ajax. UK Prime Minister Keir Starmer condemned the English ban, stressing fan safety and inclusion, and acknowledged the Tel Aviv unrest as part of a broader issue in fan security and international policing.
title: Tel Aviv Soccer Derby Canceled by Police Due to 'Violent Riots'
